Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Shelf-Basin Exchange South of Denmark Strait: Forcing, Dynamics, and Large-Scale Impact
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Irminger Sea, situated between southern Greenland and the Reykjanes Ridge, is a critically important area where the Arctic Sea first meets the North Atlantic Ocean. South of the Denmark Strait, a sharp front is formed where cold, fresh outflowing Arctic water meets the warm, salty subtropical-origin water. This front and its associated jet, the East Greenland/Irminger Current, act as the main pathway that recirculating subtropical-origin Arctic water is exported to the North Atlantic. With the stress of the down-front barrier winds adjacent to the Greenland plateau in addition to the instability and time-variability of both the front and the Irminger Current, intense shelf-basin exchange with the open Atlantic occurs in this region. As part of this exchange process, dense shelf water cascades over the shelf-break to form a "Spill Jet" which resides below the East Greenland/Irminger Current. This results in substantial sinking, which occurs downstream in the Labrador Sea and impacts the sub-polar gyre and the meridional overturning circulation to northern freshwater sources.

Currently, scientists have a poor understanding of this complex shelf-break current system, and thus are unsure of its transport, freshwater flux, seasonal evolution, and the nature and dynamics of the mesoscale variability that lead to the cross-stream exchange of mass and properties. Through a joint observational/modeling study, oceanographers from Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and Johns Hopkins University propose to quantify the hydrodynamic instability and atmospheric forcing that drive shelf-basin exchange to occur east of Greenland. By examining the mean and seasonally varying transport, structure, and kinematics of the East Greenland/Irminger Current system and determining the nature and dynamics of the mesoscale variability that leads to shelf-basin exchange, they will be able to explore how the impact of shelf-basin exchange on the sub-polar North Atlantic has changed in the last few decades and how it may evolve in the future.

The broader impacts of this study address the concern about the sensitivity of the North Atlantic meridional overturning circulation with respect to northern freshwater sources. Approximately one half of the total Arctic export of freshwater passes east of Greenland and meets the open Atlantic in the proposed study area, therefore understanding the dynamics of the shelf-basin exchange in this region is essential to potentially predict the response of the North Atlantic to future changes in climate. This research includes funding to support educational outreach including activities in a remote location in southern Greenland, as well as science center exhibits in the United States. Funding is also included to support education and training at both the graduate and undergraduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the fundamental current systems in the global ocean is the
Meridional Overturning Circulation or MOC, which helps regulate
Earth's climate. In the Atlantic, warm surface water flows poleward
representing the upper limb of the MOC. After it crosses the ridge
between Greenland and Scotland into the Nordic Seas, the water loses
heat and is transformed into cold, dense water. This dense water then
returns southward at depth, and a substantial part of it flows through
the Denmark Strait, located between Greenland and Iceland. It has long
been known that as the dense water exits the Denmark Strait it sinks
and entrains additional water, thereby forming a bottom plume that
represents the lower limb of the MOC (known as the Deep Western
Boundary Current, see the figure). Recently, however, a new current
was discovered south of Denmark Strait situated inshore and shallower
than the bottom plume, transporting slightly less dense water
equatorward. The origin of this current was unknown, as was its
significance to the MOC.

To investigate this new current and assess its importance, an array of
seven moorings was deployed across the continental slope south of
Denmark Strait for one year (autumn 2007-2008). In addition, a
shipboard survey was carried out northward through the Denmark Strait
into the Iceland Sea to investigate the different sources of water
feeding the lower limb of the MOC.

Our data revealed that the newly discovered current is a year-round
feature that transports 3-4 million cubic meters per second of water
equatorward, on par with the established bottom plume located farther
offshore. Furthermore, using the data in conjunction with numerical
simulations, we determined that the current is formed in part by dense
water that spills off the shelf south of Denmark Strait (i.e. dense
water that did not participate in the formation of the bottom
plume). As such, the new current has been named the East Greenland
Spill Jet.

We identified two different mechanisms by which the dense water is
forced off the shelf. The first mechanism is due to transient swirls
of water, known as eddies, that are associated with the bottom
plume. The eddies rotate counter-clockwise (hence they are called
cyclones) and propagate southward adjacent to the shelf. Every few
days a cyclone passes by and its leading edge draws dense water off
the shelf. The second mechanism is associated with storms. Atmospheric
low pressure systems that pass through the region frequently lead to
strong northerly Barrier Winds that force the dense shelf water
offshore. As the dense water cascades off the shelf it entrains
additional water and forms the Spill Jet (see the figure).

Our program has revealed that dense water is forced off the
continental shelf south of Denmark Strait, resulting in a permanent
southward-flowing current located inshore of the more familiar bottom
plume. This Spill Jet represents an important, heretofore
unrecognized, contribution to the Atlantic MOC.

Please see the website http://www.whoi.edu/cruise/irmingersea/ for an
account of the expedition aboard the research vessel Knorr in October
2008. The site contains essays written by professional author Dallas
Murphy, along with photographs and interaction with school children.
